120030.question: How do i hear chords in songs this is hard
120030.answer: it's no 'harder' than hearing english words when people are talking. it's actually quite impossible, but once you develop the ability it's effortless. what it takes is, just a long time of being exposed to the language (or music) with transcriptions to go along with it. and over a very very long period of exposure, eventually out of sheer curiosity you will get around to learning, forgetting, and re-learning, pretty much every different thing that ever happens. for each thing, (chord, word, pattern, thing that happens, whatever) i'd say on average it will take about 10 times learning/forgetting/re-learning the thing, and then you'll know it permanently. that being said, it's not definable how many 'things' there are, or what constitutes a 'thing', nor is it important for you to even know. but this process of learning still works like clockwork nonetheless, automatically, with enough exposure

120049.question: lately ive been haunted by the notion that an instrumental song cant stand on its own (like it needs some other thing to go along with it). so i tried making songs with lyrics and i suck at it, and ive been sucking at it for quite a while now. but whenever i try to write a song w/o lyrics i think about that notion again and it ruins the whole thing. so i think i have to either use that thought to help me make lyric songs until im good at it, or i conbince myself its not true and just make more instrumentals. until i decide im in music limbo where i cant finish anything. do you have any thoughts on that original notion i mentioned at the start? or on the situation or whatev
120049.answer: basically what you need here, is to dive head first into figuring out what really matters to you in the world, besides music. then incorporate that into music in a way that absolutely resonates with you genuinely. I too, spent most of my younger years wrapped up in only music (music music). so when it came to this point, what i did was, among other things, started freestyling text on a qwerty keyboard, from the abstract to the concrete, trying to really dig down to what means the most to me, and how i can genuinely find what i want to find, through language. after a couple of years of this, i felt more equipped with things to say and make music about, when i returned to songwriting. and i was pleasantly surprised that i was now doing it a lot differently from other songwriters, thanks to all that heck-the-out-tripping experience i'd had

120204.question: The ending of la de da de da de da de day oh is very strange and one of my favorite parts of the song. The rest was fun to transcribe and I feel it taught me a lot. But the ending feels like the song turned upside down. The song abandons any sort of recognizably melody or harmony except for the quick chords on "oh no" and even those seem to have no relation to the key of G (in fact it even sounds like they purposely clash with it), on top of the the lyrics seems to contradict some of what you said in the song. Why did you choose such a sudden and backwards ending? And if possible could tell me what the chords on "oh no" are and why you chose them. They're the only part of the song I'm not totally sure I transcribed correctly. I love the ending so much and I want to understand it more.
120204.answer: that's true all true also true being in a song, and being out of a song, are 2 drastically different worlds. regardless of whether a song has a shocking ending, it's still a very shocking transition to go from listening to a song to not listening to a song. so it often feels appropriate to incorporate elements of this shocking transition, into the song itself. for example: a door usually looks much different from the space in the room it's this in that case, that's exactly the reason i made it that way. if you've ever done something that someone else loves, i'm sure you know this feeling precisely

120303.answer: like learning a language, it doesn't really matter if you study all the way through an entire podcast (for example). if you get tired of doing that, you can just switch to a different one. 120381.question: You know how in english (or at least american english, maybe there's different ones in other english speaking countries) there's those filler words like "uh" or "um" or "so" or "like", etc. What are some of the filler words you'd hear in dutch?
120381.answer: you have uh/um. (those are pretty universal). you have "nou,", which is sometimes like the english "now," (when it doesn't mean "time"). sometimes "nou" is slightly more contradictory, like "well," in english. you have "dus" which is sort of like "so" but also like "thus" (which english doesn't use anymore). you have "soort van" which is literally "sort of", ... you have "eigenlijk" which is usually similar to "actually", you have "gewoon" which often is similar to "just", although it often appears in a different word order. you also have "even" (sounds like "effe"), which is a lot like "just" when it means "real quick". you have "zeg maar" (literally "say but") which means "so to speak", but maybe better aligns with english "i guess" added after something, for approximation. you have "een beetje" which is literallly "a bit", similar to british usage. you have "ik bedoel", literally "i mean", identical to english usage, and you have "denk ik" which means "i think" when added to the end of a phrase. you have "weet je?" literally "y'know". you have "natuurlijk" which is used like english "of course". and most of all you have "nou ja" or "naja", which often means something like "i mean yeah", or "well yeah,". And then, you have "lekker" which means tasty (or "tastily"), but it's somehow a filler word for almost all situations, whether it's something you enjoy actually or sarcastically

120478.question: what would you expect the difference between a $300 keyboard and a $1000 keyboard to be? and would the $300 one be good enough for a learner

120605.question: are sixtuplets real? aren't they just sixteenth triplets? am i trippin?
120605.answer: 'sextuplets' yes, which usually means the same thing as sixteenth note triplets. and 'sex' also means 'six' in this case, which is also the same as what you said. although none of these names are entirely specific enough, but i think the standard assumption is that simply "triplets" refers to "eighth note triplets" more specifically "3:2" eighthnote tuplets, that is 3 notes in the time where 2 eighth notes would normally fit. on the other hand, "sextuplets" is usually understood to mean "sixteenth note triplets" which is usually assumed to mean 3:2 sixteenth note tuplets, which means 3 notes fitting into the time where 2 sixteenth notes would fit. or, equivalently, 6 in the time of 4

120808.question: why do you have two recurring answers, they're like running gags, on this page? they are: "i was going to say no but now that i think about it yes" and "i would prefer to make a new one to be my favorite"? like why do you keep saying "i was going to say no but now that i think about it yes" over and over instead of actually coming up with true proper and honest answers? why are those answers specifically the two running gags?
120808.answer: first of all, i have more than 2 answers that recur from time to time. over the years with hundreds of thousands of questions, you're going to get that. "i would prefer to make a new one to be my favorite" is my honest answer to anything that asks me to choose a favorite amongst my own songs or videos. i resent the fact that you'd accuse me of being dishonest in that regard. the other one you mentioned, "i was going to say no but now that i think about it yes", is quite often an honest answer. again, i can't think of any reason you'd assume that's dishonest. This is usually the answer i give when i wouldn't have originally thought 'yes', but then after thinking about it for a moment, i realize, for the first time, that i do actually agree with the idea posed in the question. which in most cases would be something new to me at that moment. A small percentage of the use-cases for that answer are also because i just think that answer fits well with the question. sometimes it leaves room for the reader to think about it a little more, considering the implications of both a 'no' and a 'yes' answer, and the transition from one to the other. i find that answer to have a lot of different nuances depending on the question, so that's why i think i get so much mileage out of it

120907.question: Does a chord need to have all the in-between notes to be called a particular extended chord? Or just the top 2 or 3? For example, say the voicing is C G Bb Eb F. Would that be a Cm11? Or would it be a Cm7add11? Or rather an Ebadd9/G/C :) Or maybe a better example is C Bb Eb A. That sounds very 13'y to me but it doesn't have the 5 or the 9. Would that still be called a 13 then? I guess the contrapositive here might also be interesting: If a chord looks exactly like a stack of thirds, is it possible for it to not be an extension? Like stacking thirds diatonically from C up to A, is that always a C13, or could it be a Bbmaj7/Cmaj? What would have to be happening musically for it to be called a polychord? Does it just have to not resolve to F? But in the blues the four seven doesn't go a fourth up, it goes a fourth down, and it doesn't even sound like a resolution, but everyone calls it an F7 or a Bb7 or whatever.
120907.answer: sure that might be unnecessary that way might not be clear to anybody actually i'd say that's a pretty typical "Cm13", as used in real life. to include the other notes might get too crowded anyway Cm13, according to the notation conventions that i believe are still largely in play, in the professional music world, pretty much means that it includes precisely the notes you first mentioned (C, Bb, Eb, A) and this exact order you mentioned them is in fact seemingly the most useful and common, mostly i almost wanna say you're not gonna find that in real life. the only place you might find it is in a textbook, and even so, that would be a textbook that cares more about what it looks like on paper than how it actually sounds in, like, ... music and songs and stuff i'm not sure what key we're in, compared to the C, but, giving you the benefit of the doubt and assuming it is the key of F, thus being C E G Bb D F A, ...... the F note in there is really ruining things, being the reason you wouldn't call it C13, and also the being the main reason you're probably not gonna hear anyone use it like this. get rid of the F, then i guess you'd call it C13. but that's really, really, not the way C13 is actually played by anyone. this thing you're doing with note-stacking-in-3rds, it may relate vaguely to the logic of the notation, but it's just not the way those chords are ever played. you find this immediately when you sort of step out into the real world. The C13 chord symbol, as it's actually used, is generally understood to have the following features: C in the bass, A somewhere in the harmony, Bb somewhere in the harmony, E somewhere in the harmony. then, less important, D is sometimes thrown in for support, and the G honestly usually just crowds things i think the thing on the right side of the slash is understood to be just a bass note. so if you write a whole chord like that, on the right side of the slash, most professionals might not know what to do i'm not sure. i've never heard the word 'polychord' outside of extremely academic scenarios at this point, i think the best thing to do is exit the textbook and get straight into real songs, real music, and see what's going on. at first, a lot of things will surprise you -- you will find many 'rules' from your textbooks to be 'broken' in what you hear, but then you'll find just as many cool patterns that seem to hold true out there in the real music, (which you never saw in the text books), only for those to be broken again in other alternate sides of the music world. music is full of patterns to find, things that happen a certain way, but they are just as quickly defied when you move to a different region, different artist, different sort of music or different time period. have fun (it's fun)

120948.question: How do you start writing a song.
120948.answer: you can start it in a lot of different ways -- which actually means, the most important thing is that you do not have to work on the rest of it at that same time. instead, start a bunch of songs, in a bunch of different ways, in one session. remove the pressure of having to switch jobs entirely (from song starter to song finisher), and you'll get a chance to really try a whole bunch of different start-methods and start-tricks -- even try each one of them like 10 times. just make a whole pile. if even just 30% of them are good, that's gonna be a LOT of starting seeds, which your songwriting/songworking depertment will be very very pleased about later. and don't forget to log the ones that come to you by accident when you weren't even trying to do it. feeds the songworking department just the same. again, remember that you are not supposed to drop everything and go to work in the song-working department as soon as you accidentally get a good songseed start, in the middle of your trainride or whatever else. the system is working great if you just log it and continue your life. the songworking department will receive these seeds in due turn, just the same. anyway, that's how i do it

121097.question: I've been working on a project for the past couple of months, and things have been going very well. I'm not running into any big issues, and the things that I am creating are looking and feeling great. I just finished a big chunk of work on the project (that took a lot longer than expected), and I'm moving onto the next part that needs working, and I just can't do it. I'm looking at the computer, telling myself that I need to get started, and I can't seem to bring myself to do it. This is something that I've experienced before, but this is the first time I've caught myself so early in the process. It sucks too, because I'm scared of losing the projects potential, but I can't seem to get myself to fulfill it. Any tips? Maybe I just need to *quit being a baby* and grab hunker down over some coffee...
121097.answer: i think it's time to briefly describe and summarize what you've done on the project, and why you started it. which will lead you to a brief description and summary of what you think you ought to do next, and why. compare your original plan to what you think the plan ought to be now. just to make sure you are on the same page as yourself

121138.question: There is ongoing debate as to whether the art and the artist should remain separate. I believe the two should never be separated, but I think that's the wrong question. People should be asking whether the audience should be separate from the art. I think they should. What do you think?
121138.answer: this question doesn't make much sense on a surface level, but those phrasings tend to, bizarrely, mean something like this: "If an artist does or thinks something we think is bad, should we turn against them as a society? and if so, how much?" and my answer is no i don't think society should turn against them. i apologize if this does not resemble your original question. just in case, i will answer your original question more directly, by saying that i think an artist will probably be connected to the art while making it, and then they can make a decision whether to release it with their name on it or anonymously. an audience can also choose to remain separate from any piece of art, by simply not viewing it and not going near it

121295.question: are there any songs where you wrote only lyrics first, instead of writing the lyrics with some instrument in tandem? if so, can you provide some examples of which songs (that you've posted) you did it with? and do you think writing lyrics before anything else affected the strong-ness of the song
121295.answer: i've never done lyrics-first for more than one line (such as the title line). Lyrics first for an entire song can be a fun puzzle, and if you want to hear viable results of this, just listen to any Elton John song. but this method just doesn't work for me. However, what can be fun, is to dream up a title for a song. particularly something fairly long, where the title itself is fun to read. Then i'll take this line, musicalize it, and then continue writing the song from there. so only that one line was lyrics first. this is the only time where i'll use lyrics first, is only for a title line. Examples of this are "i like to wear soft clothing (cuz it makes me feel like i'm rough in comparison)", "the moon is made of cheese (but i can't taste it)", "ground plane", "the best thing about games is losing them", "i'm a huge gamer (most of the time)", and "the easter bunny told me that christmas isn't real (but santa claus is still jesus)"

121327.question: Dear Bill Wurtz, I noticed a hypocrisy. At some point someone asked " Are you more inclined to answer a sincere question over a kinda goobed one or is it just a matter of the ones that call out to you?" and you answered "all of these questions are ungoobed. the goobed ones don't even get through" meanwhile some people ask questions like: "Is mush a goup?" "Hello why are mangos yellow" "why is it that that that is is that that is not is not is not that it it is", I believe 'goobed' would be a good descriptor word for these questions. This is not a personal offence to you, I enjoy your music and think you're probably a decent person. I also understand that this is your question board where you are fully within your right to answer whatever questions you want. despite this, I still going to point it out. May you have a good day. Best regards, An Anonymous Internet user

121436.question: i'm fascinated by pretty much everything that exists, which is a problem because i have a fairly limited amount of time on this earth so learning about one thing means i have less time to learn about something else. how can i pick one thing to focus on when nothing sticks out as being cooler than the rest?
121436.answer: make a list of as many as you can think of. first, you'll notice it's fun to actually make the list, which might be what you were worried about (not getting a chance to make such a list). The list will be quite long of course, but you will actually be pleased to find out that there are actually some things that don't fascinate you. those things won't make the list. (it will feel refreshing actually, to have sharpened your sense of who you are, just that little bit). Now, with this tremendously exciting list (still very long), go ahead and start trying to learn them all at the same time, (rotating to the next one as often as desired). this will actually be quite fun for a while, because you will actually learn things. continue this way as long as desired, until you naturally develop a genuine first-hand eagerness to make much more rapid progress on one of them. this decision will come natural and confidently after knowing you've surely and earnestly made an attempt at the longer list

121493.question: it seems that two things happen as i spend more of my life working on original songs: (1) i am able to more quickly and efficiently use my songwriting tools (guitar, Logic, etc) (2) the songs i attempt to create become more ambitious (more chords, more difficult mixing techniques) which makes me slower. so in the end my song production rate doesn't seem to be increasing. at this rate it will take me years to make an album. would you recommend in this case working on very short songs to streamline my song factory?

121600.question: i always get stuck on the beginning of everything. i have a perfectly clear vision of what i want the end product to look like, but when i actually have to do the transition from idea generating to idea materializing, i can barely get anything out. any help?

If you don't know, then you have 2 choies: learn from how someone else does it, or invent your own way. so in summary that's 3 possible scenarios: explain the procedure to prove you know it, or learn the procedure from someone else, or invent your own procedure. those 3 cases can break down further once you figure out which one you are in, but hopefully that should point you in the right direction

121767.question: god, i just love "i'm a princess" so much. it's the riff that gets me the most, i think. it's so comforting yet so bouncy and funky... how did you get the idea for the making of the song? like, what kind of inspiration or thoughts went into making the instrumentals, lyrics, etc?
121767.answer: i was specifically considering what i wanted my next released song to be. it's not always the case that i write things directly to be up next for production, in fact usually this doesn't happen. but i was specifically looking for something with a strong title and a strong opening. the line "i'm a princess" suddenly came to mind. and then i just continued writing from there. as usual, there's no real way to explain any of the specifics of how or why any of the notes chords words and sounds came about, it's just business as usual, in the magic of songwriting

121843.question: When making a song, in what order should you record the different instruments and the vocals? Say you're making a song with guitar, drums, bass guitar, vocals, and keyboard just as an example?

121935.question: These days I tend to get maybe about 1.5 minutes into writing a song no problem before hitting walls, because at that point writing further can become time consuming and maybe even tedious, since usually you have to do full run throughs and hope the ether gives you what happens next. I will say I hit that wall in writing today and tried that idea of making it bad on purpose, and it literally completely worked and propelled the whole thing forward into the right direction. I think the idea works because fundamentally good songs play, like play around, and trying something bad to throw a wrench in the whole thing is sometimes the right chaos and the order / clean up that follows feels so good. Kinda weird. Would you agree with that, or do you think it's silly to try to figure out the secret sauce behind the secret sauce of trying something bad on purpose

121961.question: is english a better lingua franca than other existing languages? is it just by happenstance that it became a lingua franca? in my mind, it seems like any language could work since, for example, i've met native greek- and turkish-speakers in germany speaking german. but also i could see an argument that english is such an amalgamation of other languages that it sounds equally foreign wherever it's spoken.

121962.question: Hey, my question basically could be summarized as "how did you develop yourself as a musician?" (out of curiosity), and also, maybe, "how do you 'understand/(feel about)' music?", but unsure about that last one. Also, sorry if I ask too much and feel free to omit [not answer everything]. Relatively recently, I got more curious than I've ever been about music. And I found on the internet that you're self-taught and (from what I understand) that you don't really like music theory, and say that music can't really be described like that [sorry if I oversimplfy or misunderstand some stuff]. Which sounds kinda like the approach I would want to take to understand music better and/or maybe even write some of my own music later on. I think what sparkled my curiosity in music, was that some particular songs made me feel specific feelings, some songs being especially intense in that (a large amount of feeling ignited) [How did you get into music? (curiosity)]. So, that made me curious why those songs in particular and how do they make me feel such intense feelings [Do you have songs that made you experience similar things? Do you have the means (what sort of means? how did you get those means?) to explain that, or did you just accept the feelings without questioning them? (Other?)]. It seems to me that the two most important things in a song to me are "feeling" and "story". "Story" isn't necessarily lyrics; it could be fully instrumental song, it just may feel like the melody is still telling a story. And "feeling" is 'simply' the fact that melody evokes particular feelings. So, if I were to compose music, I feel like I would want to have these 2 [Do you have "similar" ideas about music, that you possibly apply to composing your own pieces of music?] The problem is that I know like nothing about music, and when I'm behind the keyboard I basically can do only hit random keys, and actually they sometimes provide some melodies(, etc) that sound somewhat adequate, and I actually made one into somewhat of a song. So, while this random hitting could provide some ideas, and maybe it is the way to discover music vocabulary, I am completely clueless as to how to transfer the feeling and the story with some sort of intent. And maybe my story/feeling idea isn't even the right approach to making music after all. [How did you start to compose music, and how did that change over time?] And finally, while I am at it (at asking bajilion questions): 1. How did you learn to sing while being self-taught? I would be curious to learn how to sing (at least a bit, for the sake of understanding music), but this one feels by far the scariest, as to not pick up bad habits, improper techniques, and not injure throat. 2. How did you develop your "ear"? In particular, how was the "the high class stuff" video made? The transcription of pitches of the speaking voice and the insane rhythms in it (weird rests ("offbeat"?), weird durations, triplets, quintuplets). This text is so large so that I have to thank you just for reading it, and also thanks for answering on top of that.
121962.answer: music is an irresistibly strong magical power. it's a no brainer for me to develop that to the best of my ability. the first time i got hooked on it was certainly too early in my life to recall. it was before i learned to speak you can spend many lifetimes trying to explain exactly how this stuff works. i've certainly given it an earnest try from time to time. and as far as i know, no one really knows. although i'm sure someone will try to tell you they know from all the years of trying to 'understand' 'why' this stuff works, or what's really going on, a few basic principles tend to keep emerging. one theme is "making patterns, and then breaking them", which of course can be applied recursively as the make-break becomes its own pattern which in turn can be broken. And another strong theme that comes up is the idea that you have to prove you're really there right but as soon as the sound comes out you realize it's not random at all i think with enough time and experience it's gonna work fine. like learning a language, it may take years, but inevitably you will get there if you just find a way to keep enjoying it and being curious at a certain point you start to notice that you come up with ideas when you're not trying to, or when you're not supposed to. and then when you really try to, you clam up. gradually you start to learn how to strategically get that all sorted out, but it's taken me years upon years upon years upon years. maybe the first time i really wrote anything was like 6 or 7 years after i was first introduced to music, but then it was many many many many years later before i had anything with words in it, and then a few more heaps of years more before i did anything you've ever heard from me, surely just doing it a lot, it usually gets better the more you do it. at some point i heard some hints about how to not hurt yourself, but most of the technical desctiptions of how to breathe and use this and that muscle and whatever, didn't make any sense to me. i've had far more success thinking of it in terms of acting. thinking of it as a form of communication i'm not sure, but it occurs to me to ask you how you think you learned how to write and spell so well, in english. whatever mechanism that is, it's pretty much the same thing. and it also takes a lot of time probably

121995.question: Sometimes I think that it is unnessecary for me to know the distinction between turtles and tortoises. Why can't I just think that they are all turtles? Like, only people who work with animals oughtto know that tortoises are different, since that's important for them. Butthen I realise that there's probably wayyy more comlicated and nuanced differences and facts about turles and tortoises and animals that they know and I don't, so I actually know a normal amount. And then I wonder why I'm soobsessed with limiting my own knowledge. Surely that can't be healthy, noropen-minded, and I should cherish that I know turtles and tortoises are different, yes? But then, what is the ignificance of the cognitive distinction, if it is likely that I will never need to pick one out of a crowd of the other? Although, it's unlikely that a shark is heading straight for me, but it would help to know how to stop it from getting me. Should I relax on the whole knowledge thing, or is there really no reason in seperating turtles and tortoises in my mind?
121995.answer: you can. everything has to be approximated somewhere. do you realize how different some houses are from other houses, and yet the word house remains surprisingly useful if you leave the turtle thing aside, this will only bring opportunities to learn other things that are more important to you. you're not obsessed with limiting your knowledge, but what you do have is a lot of analytical energy, to the point where you're on the verge of trying to open your mind in multiple ways at once, some of which may be contradictory to each other there are equal joys to be had at every level of tortoise/turtle awareness spectrum you may not need to, but what if you WANT to you don't have to. i think your best bet at this point is to pursue your curiosities. the brain is maybe at its most powerful when it's curious. so you can't go wrong there to put it in perspective, in some regions, the word for "soda" is "coke". so therefore Coke and Pepsi would both be considered different kinds of coke

122281.question: hi i like your music and i have a question. do you ever do synth production. do you perhaps have any tips. thanks bill wurtz from music.
122281.answer: sometimes what works best for me is to get things that i can play. things that respond immediately to note-on, and note-off. things that respond to how loud or soft i hit the note. and then the other really powerful ingredient is to set something to one of the wheel controls, so i can manipulate that with the other hand while playing. things i find most useful for wheel assignment are usually filter cutoff, vibrato, or maybe some sort of noise level. these are the things that suit me best, because my strong point is my playing. so the kind of things, for example, that i don't want, would be something that does a whole mess of things without me touching it, where my playing wouldn't affect anything

122328.question: I remember in 2018 when I saw your Mt st Helen's video and thought the world was about to end and all the rich people were building space ships to escape the coming nuclear Armageddon . Like I was some sort of a messiah receiving hidden messages from your videos. That's why I started sending you crazy messages. It made me feel special . I now realize how crazy I was . I have a hard time coming to terms with the fact that I'm just like everyone else . I suppose I'm writing this so at least I will be remembered for how retarded I really was . I know how funny it probably sounds to you and you have every right to laugh at me. Moral of the story ? Don't do 500mg edibles before watching YouTube
122328.answer: it's not unheard of to have the experience you've had. while your logic during that time may not have been entirely sound, it doesn't mean that you have to be exactly like everyone else either. what i'm saying is, there is a realm somewhere in between joe-normal total-messiah. can be hard to find sometimes, but now that you've seen both ends of the spectrum maybe you have better chance now at finding that sweet spot

122351.question: Hi Bill, I hope to find you well in these trying times for the world. Just recently I rediscovered your music after learning almost all of it by memory years ago, and remembering about this questions section on your website I wanted to drop by to say I love your music. As an electronic music student, I can't help but be amazed at the intricacy of your compositions. You manage to use harmony, groove and timbre as tools to craft relatable vibes, along with lyrics that - a way to put it for me is that they reveal a certain depth of character and life experience, also relatable, and something one could learn and take inspiration from as a person. All this said, I look forward to dive into new music of yours in the future! Hope you're having a good time, and take good rest on summer vacations! 122449.question: Hi Bill. I've been thinking about this topic for a few years now and I'm wondering if you have some more insight into it and experience with this same thought pattern... and hopefully some sort of an swer or solution that can help me out. I'm in sort of a thou ght loop to do with productivity, goals, and doing the things I WANT to be doing, but find myself NOT doing. For example, I'm a musician as well and I want to be writing more music and practicing piano more. I'm also a drumme r and keep up with that because I'm currently in a band, which is something holding me to improving and being creative... all that. The problem is, I have nothing holding me to writing songs in any particular time frame, or m aking me practice piano, practice singing... etc. I have FLStudio and want to put some more time into learning the platform, but I'm struggling a lot with the learning curve of even starting out and making something simple. Basically what my question boils down to is this: how do I get myself to do the delayed gratification things I WANT to be working t owards and improving at when all I seem to want to do is quick dopamine rel ease like watching YouTube and playing video games? I'm in a weird spot on my thoughts about it because part of me thinks "I have my whole life to wri te music, make an album I'm proud of, (insert long term goal), etc... so ea ch day it seems almost pointless to start, and very difficult to find the m otivation to do it and enjoy doing it. Should I wait until the days I decid e I feel like working on something and very slowly work towards my goals, o r set more attainable short-term goals to keep me on track? I've tried both and I still feel like I could be making more progress... I feel like I'm g onna end up 45 years old and still not comfortable and capable on piano and all that and still struggling to write anything, wishing I used the hours of free time I had when I was younger... I know this is a fucking essay at this point but, thoughts on all that? Have you found your self thinking similar things? Is it really enough to just very slowly work towards it when I feel the motivation? Thanks.
122449.answer: hear me out on this: start a new tv series, on which you try to approach the problem

122903.question: The anxiety and pressure that comes whenever I have an idea or impulse to create something, is like, unbearable. The more exciting and important the idea is, the more intense the fear is. usually completely ignore the creative impulse, and then I just feel so plagued and like I've failed at my mission in life. It happens so often over the years that it's developed into a distrust of myself. Any advice? Solidarity?
122903.answer: i am guessing this will work for you: start cultivating a continuous list of ideas. the more the better. what you'll find is, the coolest thing about ideas is that you never know which one is going to turn out which way. so it's actually fun to pepper an idea list with quite 'bad' or 'useless' ideas. you never know which ones are the winners anyway. but the real important thing here is you need to take the pressure off the individual idea. the list method is probably a great cure for that

122908.question: I was intrigued when you recently said surrealism is a "mild connective agent that you only need from time to time". What do you consider surrealism then? I had always understood it as a sort of thoughtless creation, like a spilling out of creation without premeditation or intent.
122908.answer: you left out the context. that was in the context of someone asking me whether i think i am a 'surrealist'. so the answer i gave was in relation to the work that i do i was thinking surrealism is something that really doesn't resemble anything that can be described in words. so i think what i was trying to say is, it's good to have more recognizable elements as anchors, and surrealism works perfectly well but if the whole thing is completely unidentifiable then you might feel a little lost. but it's important to remember that i did not bring up the word surrealism in this situation. so all of my analyses here are somewhat on the back foot, as i'm trying to incorporate the word (surrealist) originally suggested in the question, which might not be a word i would have chosen to use for anything

123127.question: How do you feel about using a fade out to end a song? Off the top of my head, I can't think of a song by you that ends in a fade (although I'm sure there's probably a couple?). But I can't think of any others. I feel like a fade out could be a useful tool when you want to imply that the music could go on forever, but sometimes when I hear fade outs in songs it almost just sounds like the band is still playing and the producer just decided "this is getting too long, I'm just gonna fade it out here to shorten the run time".

123206.question: What if a lot of the things that people blame on capitalism was actually feudalism's fault all along? For example, occupational surnames seem to imply that you are your job, but they date back to the Middle Ages. Meanwhile, due to the Industrial Revolution making labor more efficient, people have more free time, and they get to have a "work-life balance" with "hobbies". Not everyone works on a farm because not everyone needs to work on a farm. People aren't separated into castes like lords, vassals, and peasants; they can change how much money they earn. Don't get me wrong; the poor get poorer and never any richer, and you are not the car you drive or the contents of your wallet and all that. But I think some clarity on the issue of capitalism is much needed. Thoughts?

123297.question: As I write more songs, I'm finding it's really easy for me to write choruses and bridges the repetitive or most important parts of the song that reveal the core way that I feel about something. These are usually the things I write first, the first things I come up with. As I then have to expand on those ideas, I find it's difficult to put together verses or pre-choruses. I feel like I'm out of things to say. I think part of the problem is that these are usually the parts of other peoeple's songs I find least interesting. Like, my favorite "musical moments" are often choruses or bridges, and I don't usually think about verses. Ofcourse there are great lyrical moments that I think about all the time, but those are few and far between I suppose. It's like, I just wrote the best part of this song, and now you want me to... write a less interesting part? I don't know how to expand on my ideas in that way. Does that make sense? What do I do?
123297.answer: the first thing i'd absolutely recommend to any songwriter, forget everything you know about the names of the sections. "chorus", "verse", these terms play dirty and no one truly knows which is which, or if songs even need to have them, whatever. The important thing is, you've come up with the most important part, the best part. so you know you have that to offer. make the rest of the song about how good the main part is, and how excited you are to have people hear it. remember this 'additional contents' can be as short as you want, it can be after or before, in between, anywhere, and it does not have to be called a 'verse' or 'pre-whatever'. any amount of anything anywhere, in service of the main gift piece you are offering. in fact it's always good to first just ask yourself if maybe you don't even need anything else. and then just do whatever you need to deliver the goods. it's like you've got the birthday gift, all you need is the box. just put it in something and get it there, so it can be opened and enjoyed

123568.question: This may be a dumb question (as in there may be a glaringly obvious answer that I'm overlooking)... but is there a way to calculate the square root of a number without having a calculator or other device with a square root button? Like, how would you figure out the square root of a number using only +,-,×, and/or ÷?
123568.answer: what i would do, for example, to find the square root of 7, is guess and check and keep narrowing the window. 2 squared is 4, and 3 squared is 9. so it's between 2 and 3. multiply by 100 to make it easier. 20 squared is 400, 30 squared is 900. so the square root of 700 is between 20 and 30. .....25 squared is 625...... so it's more than 25. ... 26 squared is 676. ....the difference between those last 2 results is 51, so i know it's gonna be 53 up to the next (27 squared = 729). ok so it seems like 26.5 is gonna be pretty close to the square root of 700. add more digits and say what's 265 squared, i mean that's a little heavy perhaps to do in your head, but you said you're allowed to use "+,-,×, and/or ÷", so, 265 squared is ... (260x260 + 5x5 + 260x5x2) which is (67600 + 25 + 2600) which is 70225. so that's...... fairly close. this means 2.65 squared is 7.0225. maybe we can check 264 squared -- just take the previous result and subtract 264 and 265. so 70225 minus 529 is 69696. so that means 2.64 squared is 6.9696. it looks like the answer is about half way in between the two previous results. so 2.645 is getting closer still. if you want to keep narrowing it down, you'd have to add more digits, and check 2645 squared, and see which side of 7000000 it's on, then check the one on the other side, and do the same thing again. but we've got it down to approximately 2.645, without a calculator

123625.question: how to extend attention span for lengthy instrumental pieces that you are familiar or unfamiliar with? I'm thinking classical symphonies but it could be jazz improvs etc. Do you follow along with the sheet music if it exists? Do you try to focus on non-melody parts like the bass and inner harmonies as a challenge? Do you visualize the melodies as notes of a piano roll? Do you try to imagine movie scenes that could go along with the music? Do you make yourself feel as if what you are about to hear is heavenly, so that you are positively predisposed? Do you channel your inner Leonard Bernstein and air-conduct an imaginary symphony orchestra in your bedroom? Basically the question is, how to hang from the first note and keep flying till the last note (paraphrasing Daniel Barenboim here), so that I can thorougly enjoy a piece of music and make my brain shut up and listen?
123625.answer: those are all great suggestions, but in this case i'm a little disappoointed in the artist for leaving you totally high and dry on this, and not even attempting to provide you with ANYTHING in this department. it almost makes me wonder why you are so determined to listen to these artists when, let's face it, their product has fallen just shy of being compelling enough for you to enjoy in its given form

123676.answer: i don't write lyrics separately. i write the song together most of the power of songs functions on a sort of unexplainable level. most writers and artists would agree that they don't quite have any idea how the ideas come and where they come from. most of us feel it comes 'through' us when it's working properly. i've never heard of anyone getting good results from making decisions about how they "think" a song "should" be. in fact sometimes the best results seem to defy any expectations you might have had

123926.question: i want to learn romanian, should i go down the youtube route or duolingo?
123926.answer: this is the method i recommend: find genuine conversational content in the language, with accurate transcriptions. this can be harder to find for more obscure languages, but that is what you need. auto-transcribe is usually not quite good enough to be reliable, so it's better to get something that has been truly and accurately transcribed by a real person. genuine conversational content, by real native speakers (not made-up textbook scenarios, you need real people really talking naturally). then run the transcript through a translator and then just start getting curious about what means what. let your curiosity drive you. maybe even start fixing the mistakes of the transcription. after a few weeks you can start guessing the translation based on the written transcript, and then, after a few months, you can start trying to transcribe just based on the audio alone. in addition to this, continue listening/watching the content casually in your free time. and most importantly, be patient. this will take years. it doesn't take skill, it takes time and curiosity. don't worry about speaking. just keep spending more and more time listening and breaking down what you're hearing, listening, listening more, and eventually after a few years the language will automatically start spilling out of your mouth

124026.question: what's the craziest coincidence you've been a part of
124026.answer: i had an unfinished project at the end of the school year. i wasn't going to pass the class, except my teacher allowed me to drop it off at the end of the last day, during final exams for my other classes, and then i would pass. i was able to finish the project during my final exams for the other classes, and i ended up dropping it off by the end of the day. Later, i got a voice mail message from that same teacher, the message was for 'bill' and she was saying that i still hadn't turned in that project, and if i didn't then i wasn't going to pass the class. of course i knew that i actually HAD turned in the project. so her message made perfect sense except for that one detail. And here's why: there was another student named Bill, in another one of her classes, who was in the same situation, who hadn't finished that same project, would have not passed if he didn't complete it, and his phone number was almost the same as mine, and she dialed my number by mistake. so she dialed the wrong number (mine) and delivered a voice mail message to someone (me) who had the same name and was almost in the exact same situation as the other person who's number she meant to dial

124061.answer: there are a lot of advantages and disadvantages to both. living in the city can be very validating. it can remind you that you have a healthy ability to be normal and do normal things like a normal person. i guess not everyone needs that reminder. but i think if i lived in the middle of nowhere, i'd start to become too insecure that i actually am not even fit to live on this planet

124341.question: Does the circle of 5ths serve a purpose other than being a tool to help people memorize what notes are sharp/flat in a key signature? I got comfortable playing in all 12 keys and knowing the sharps/flats before I ever even saw/knew about that circle of 5ths graphic. I guess it visually shows the relationships between different key sigs (which is cool), but not sure if I understand the practical use of it when it comes to actually playing music? I think if you want to learn how to play in a certain key, you kind of need to build up that muscle memory of what it 'feels like' for your hands to be playing in that key. Knowing that A major has a C#, F# and G# doesn't mean you can just freely/easily play in A major on the spot (if you're not already comfortable playing in that key). I guess the circle helps you quickly figure out what notes are in the key, but I can only see that being helpful in a practice situation... And if you're just practicing, you can just, like... look up the notes of the scale on the internet...
124341.answer: it's a tool to make your keyboard not sound like crap. but the work has already been done. you don't need to worry about it. your keyboard is already tuned to 12-tone-equal-tempered (which is what makes the keys all wrap around neatly like that), so the work has already been done. enjoy your keyboard sounding like not-crap in every key the graphic is just telling about a cool pattern. it's something you'd probably notice by yourself anyway if no one had told you. it's like when someone tells you the last digit of multiples of 9 gets one lower each time. neat. the numbers still work fine regardless of whether you know about that, or whether or not you think it's neat wait a minute, forgive me for asking this, but, .......... is your keyboard muted or something?

124503.question: help, i'm non-binary, how do i read and understand binary (the 0s and 1s text)?

124566.question: I'm autistic, but I have a not autistic friend and they told me that you do not always answer in a straight forward way in your answers. Sometimes you say the opposite of the answer you really mean. I would ask if this is true, but I would have no idea if the answer you give is the true or the opposite of what is true. Apparently people don't always just say direct answers to questions and I don't understand why. Apparently that is autism, but it seems more to me like everyone else is the weird one for not just answering questions directly. And if everyone else knows that you can never know if someone is answering a question directly and honestly, how does anyone function?
124566.answer: perhaps the problem is that total complete honesty would take an infinite amount of time to express. to answer finitely, requires an absurd amount of simplifation, and the answerer may have to make some big decisions about how to go about doing that. in some cases it may turn out that stronger meaning can be approximated better by going at sort of an oblique angle from the question, especially if there are other important issues that weren't even covered in the question. For example, let's say there is a Tsunami approaching. your friend asks you "what's 2 plus 2". and instead of saying "4", you answer "aaaaah there's a Tsunami approaching"

For example there's no way it's the proper meaningful way of the world for some dude to be pushed in front of a subway train and killed, yet this happens multiple times a year. Like I know all this is still true and yet I don't care about it in better points in my life, but now that I'm in a low point I need to figure out how to stop hating the world so much as it's just making me grumpy and unproductive. 125210.question: Ok, so I was thinking about chairs, like that chair over there. Not a specific chair, just any chair, and then I wondered "I wonder what would happen if chairs were sentient and were able to voice their opinions?" And then that's when I started asking "I wonder how they'd react to being used by someone?" would they react like "Oh wow, thank you my use is being fulfilled!" or would it be more like "Hello, can you please stop sitting on me? that is very rude." But then each chair has their own different opinion, so each chair would feel very different from each other about the whole "people create chairs to sit in chairs" thing. Maybe some chairs are just too shy to talk about it and prefer to stay quiet so they don't offend anyone. Maybe the other chairs caught on to this and have decided to take a vow of silence so they don't overwhelm each other with their opinions. Am I onto something with this? Or am I thinking too deeply about chairs?

125212.question: I keep hearing advice along the lines of "good writers are good because they have something to say; they don't just write for the sake of writing" but I fear I will never have enough to say that I will become a good writer about it. advice ?
125212.answer: that sounds backwards, actually. Sometimes people who aren't writers have something so important to say that they write it anyway, despite not normally being a writer. Writers, on the other hand, love writing so much that they're just going to keep writing no matter what. but regardless, there's infinite things to say anyway, so you're gonna end up saying things no matter what. if you try to avoid writing because you think there's nothing to say, then you'll never even get a chance to improve, and then you'll have to try to tell other writers not to write either, to prevent them from getting ahead of you

125363.question: what are the reasons a lowercase I would be better, for referencing yourself? what if You, He, She, and They were all capital as well (when referring to people)
125363.answer: the capital i is a disaster because it's not as distinctive as a single letter word needs to be. in some fonts it looks the same as lower case L. when a word is only 1 letter, you need as much distinction as possible, for clarity. the lower case i with the dot is very distinctive, and much easier to recognize. The second reason is because the dot on the i can be seen like an eye, giving it a more personal feel. in addition to these reasons NOT to capitalize that particular word, i also have no idea what good it does to capitalize it, and other languages don't do it either. of all the pronouns, it's kind of hilarious that we choose that one to capitalize

125380.question: From what I can tell, you have some form of perfect pitch. To what extent do you think this helps you when making/recording/playing music? For people like me who were not blessed with the gift of perfect pitch, do you think we're at much of a disadvantage compared to people like you who do? Do you think your musical abilities, and your music itself, would be much different if you didn't have perfect pitch at all?
125380.answer: if you learn the note names based on absolute pitch in early life, i think that might actually hurt your music. music is all in the relationships between the notes. finding the absolute is just a party trick i learned later in life, which has a limited number of random professional benefits. to compare it to cooking, absolute pitch would be like memorizing the UPC codes of all your ingredients, where as relational pitch would mean you can taste what they actually do. i myself was actually surprised to find out how truly unmusical the absolute pitch is. which is also what makes it so confusing that the phrase 'perfect pitch' is something that sounds like it means your pitch is perfect, but it neither means that nor is musical

125453.question: I saw this form of musical notation in a question asked to you on August 14, 2018: "3/4 3..45./2...../1..23./lo7...../lo6.lo7.1./lo5...3./4..321/2...../ 3..45./2...../1..23./lo7...3./4.3.1./1...lo7./1.1235/8.1.../"; you mentioned in your answer that this is a form of notation you use as well when you only have access to text to write music. It looks interesting and efficient, but I can't make heads or tails of it. Would you mind explaining this form of notation, to a musician-in-training who's used to standard music notation?
125453.answer: this person's notation system is very clear to me. they did a good job presenting all the necessary melodic information, specifically the pitch and the rhythm. they are using numbers for scale degrees, so for example in the key of C that would be 1=C, 2=D, etc. They've indicated the rhythm clearly making every note the same length, and using dots do fill equal sized spaces with no notes. The slashes are clearly barlines. thanks to their time-signature hint at the top (3/4) we can assume that each digit or dot represents an eighth note of time. Also very useful is that they are distinguishing notes in different octaves by saying "lo7" to represent the 7 below the 1, and so on. So the melody is represented quite clearly and precisely. Information that is NOT included here: chords, tempo, and note duration. However, this particular melody is so strong and familiar the chords are just about totally obvious

125547.question: Any tips for learning a new language?
125547.answer: the way i approach a brand new language is this: find some videos of people having real conversations (not scripted) like podcasts or something like that. the more you enjoy the content, the better. but you also need it to have a reliable human-made transcript. then get the transcript translated. then just start getting curious about which sounds mean what, and go from there. listening is king, but the transcript will unlock what you're hearing. a crucial important tip is do NOT expect yourself to 'remember' or 'memorize' anything. that's just not how it works. with more and more and more and more and more exposure, whilst being curious, the brain will do what it does naturally, which is learn. your brain is much better at learning than you will ever understand. trust that this will happen naturally with enough exposure and curiosity. the only other thing that may throw you off is how ridiclulously long it takes

125572.question: can your tips for language learning be applied to learning musical improv (listen to a recording of improv, find/create a transcript, don't expect to memorize it, spend a lot of time)?

125673.question: Does it bother you when the music at a place doesn't fit the place's atmosphere? For instance, last night I went to a nice Belgian restaurant. It was rather elegant, with good-quality (if a bit overpriced) food, and a rather elderly clientele. However, they were playing EDM/rave music at full blast in there throughout the whole time we were there, and while it didn't seem to bother everyone else too much, it drove me nuts. I'm not a particular fan of that kind of music, but that's not what bothered me about it-what bothered me was that it didn't match the restaurant's atmosphere and ambiance at all. In fact, it seemed to be a continued disturbance to the atmosphere, and it stuck out like a sore thumb. It was too bad, because I liked the food, and the decoreverything else was enjoyable, except the music. Do things like this ever happen to you? 125851.question: Hypothetical situation- let's say you're drawing numbers out of a hat, the numbers are written on paper, same size, numbered 1-20 and one of each. You draw the number 17. You put it back, shake the hat to mix it up, draw agin, it's 17 again. Repeat. By pure chance you draw the number 17 a bunch of times in a row, technically possible right? Here's my question- with each 17 that you draw, do your chances of it being 17 get higher or lower? I know that the technical answer is that the chances get lower, but for some reason I have this weird feeling that the universe would recognize the pattern and your chances might get higher to fulfill it.
125851.answer: the technical answer is that the chances should always be the same, not lower in a real world situation, it would probably become somewhat likely that some kind of trickery or defect could be happening at this point. so in that sense, there would be a nonzero chance that it is a trick and therefore the trick might continue this way. but if you can be sure you've eliminated any chance of such trickery, then the chances are the same each time

125865.question: Should I set set myself a deadline? I think I thought about setting a deadline and then thought that I did but was so unconsciously unsure of the merits of setting a deadline that I didn't fully commit to setting it and then didn't follow it because it wasn't set with full commitment. On the one hand, setting a deadline lets me know how much I need to divide my work over time and lets me know when to stop working, but on the other hand if my work isn't finished before the deadline, it will never be finished because it's past the deadline and i've stopped working on it.

125885.question: Lately I've been thinking about what causes stalled progress in the creative process. Why excitement for a goal dwindles the closer you get to achieving it. I've noticed the struggle usually occurs when I hit some sort of road block. Almost always when the experience of *doing it* stops being fun. Instead of asking "how can I push through it?" I wanted to know what you do to make the process enjoyable again? When I try to coerce it into a desired outcome it only makes it worse. Sorta like it's protesting or arguing with me in some weird way. So how do you invite the play back into it and help things move more freely? Thanks.
125885.answer: like untangling a cable, ultimately you need to find the end (or start) of the cable. Basically what you need to do is open up a conversation with a friend (or, you know, rubber duck, or maybe just a television camera / yourself) and explain what this project is, for those of us who don't know. like just explain how you got into this whole mess. that will be like finding the end of the cable, suddenly you'll be able to see perfectly clearly what the point of this thing was all along

126149.question: im so full of inspiration but cant create anything new when i sit down and try. suggestions?
126149.answer: yes, i use the following 2-sided approach: first sharpen your 'catch' skills, so when you get those good ones when you are way way outside the office, you have infrastructure to catch them. even if it's just catching like 1 line, you've caught it. file it away for when you're ready for it. but then to supplelement that, as a separate exercise, you can also sometimes sit down and try to come up new things that are terrible. the twist here that makes it more fun is you are allowed to make them terrible, and do like 20 or 30 of them. heck, make 29 the same and the last one different. how hard could that be if they are all supposed to be terrible. but then, the other twist, and i almost didn't wanna tell you this part, but a side-effect of these brute-force writing sessions is they will also make it even more often that you get good ideas away from the office, which hopefully you have learned to catch, as part of the first part of this advice

126151.question: what is the best response to "true or false: this sentence is false"
126151.answer: half of the sentence has a 50% chance of being false and a 50% chance of being true. the other half, on the other hand, has a 50% chance of being true and a 50% chance of being false. what's guaranteed is that the 2 halves "this sentence" and "is false" have opposing boolean status to each other. ALSO: because the 2 halves directly refer to each other, that means the sentence is not complete because there is no grounding. like if you point 2 mirrors directly at each other, you won't see anything unless there are some non-mirror objects somehow involved (such as yourself, to be able to even view it). so inconclusion the sentence is 50% incomplete, and it's 50% likely that each half is the incomplete half, and independently also 50% likely that each half is the true half. Is the above paragraph true or false?

126180.question: I like that thing that happens sometimes in songs where an unfinished lyric is repeated in kind of an unresolved melody, then the lyric finishes climacticly as the melody/harmony resolves. There's also this live version of You Make Me Feel So Young where Sinatra ends it with "You make me feel so, you make me feeeeel so... Oh, you!... Make me feel, sooooooo..... 126213.question: a couple years ago i distinctly remember reading = a response on here that went something along the lines of "use as few chords as possible when writing a song" --i've been haunted by this ever since. the more i dig into your music, the more i realize just how much of it is founded on the most rudimentary I's, IV's, and V's, despite all the crazy fills and modulations. when i write, i often find myself getting distracted by the more lush and colorful sound of upper extensions, as well as lots of dramatic chord movements. i've trained my brain to prioritize those kinds of sounds, and it feels like anything else sounds, regrettably, "plain". but i feel oftentimes that it undermines my music in the grand scale of things; i'd do ANYTHING to go back in time to before i was so mired in jazz theory. do you have any advice on achieving this sort of "harmony nirvana" that you seem to have? it's as if you know perfectly where to place all the surprising and exciting harmonic moments without compromising simplicity. tl;dr: as a theory-obsessed berklee dropout, how can i learn the confidence to use more "basic" or "boring" chords in my music?
126213.answer: that's really not something i would say. there may have been some very specific context where that would be appropriate, but it really does not sound like something i would say. various times in my life i have heard people say that kind of thing and it doesn't quite sit well with me. that being said, the opposite doesn't sit well either of course please don't give me credit for that. this is something you either thought of yourself, or heard from someone else (a lot of people say it actually) probably trying to address their concerns that people may be using the opposite strategy, which doesn't really make sense either i think you're looking in the wrong place. in fact, just the order and pattern to which you listed the chords you just listed, gives me a clue that you might be looking in the wrong place for this i find you can't actually prove which part extends from which and when how do you feel about melodies you seem to be walking backwards all the time. all this 'how to not'. sounds like youve got a case of the 'how to nots'. so 'how to not have a case of the how to nots?' well actually i think in your case, hear me out, ........ i think you should try to write the most academically advanced musical composition the world has ever seen. (seen?..... wait no actually yes.) i'm just pursuing what excites me most. i took a random quasi-satirical guess just now at what might excite you, but that might be unfair.... the point is, i see you back-stepping away from anything that might truly thrill you, and then backstepping back away from the alternative because of course it doesn't thrill you enough. Whatever your thrills may be, ....... you must go toward them. or, if it's more thrilling, do a fake-out and go briefly away from them and then slam back toward them, and so on why settle for just scratching the surface..... go for a world record. make the most boring song ever made. heck, you'd be famous immediately if you actually achieved that

126236.question: how do i increase my productivity while sitting in my bedroom working on my computer? i guess the only REALLY rigid requirement is that i still need to access my computer for the projects i'm working on, but it just feels too laid back and unstructured and i can do whatever, access whatever, and i end up spending houuuuurs not working or doing anything remotely productive towards my goals. thoughts? does going to work in a public space (library) help, or maybe just locking my computer down so much that i can't access anything? i feel like i need to trick myself into being productive, because it's the only way i've ever managed to do it before (tricking myself into believing a schedule has actual pressure, tricking myself into using todo lists, etc). the problem is that my brain will 100% of the time EVENTUALLY see through the trick, and it'll stop working. so i feel like i need something material. it feels pretty grim, though, because i've been having this issue for literal years now, and my life is just ticking on by. so..... if you've got any advice it'd be much appreciated. thanks
126236.answer: at the risk of saying the same thing i say over and over and over and over and over and over and over again, it seems glaringly obvious that there is a huge missing variable in this equation. you're talking all about whether or not you're able to do the _____, when you might try to do the _____, how to stop being distracted with things other than the _____ ........ forgive me but the whole solution is what goes in that blank and W.H.A.T. it is and learning everything about it. The kind of fun thing about this is to think about this 'what' issue at any time. chew away at 'what exactly is this', you can think about this while you're in bed, when you are waiting in line for the other line you have to wait in, these are the best times to just get curious about exactly what this whole thing is and why it ever was so exciting. everything else becomes such a non-issue compared to the this 'what' question, sorry for repeating myself and sorry also about when i explain it again soon

126335.question: Do you find it important to have a "half understanding" of an art form so you can discover entirely new methods as to creating a piece? I ask this because I have really wanted to compose many pieces of music, but I find myself easily overwhelmed and demotivated. I know how to read music and I myself can play a few instruments. I find myself so immersed into music and I generate melodies and sometimes even whole songs in my head. However, when I try to put it on paper, nothing comes out, which is weird because I can perfectly hear every detail of the music in my head but actually notating it gives me difficulty. This is likely more common than I think, but that's not the main point I want to make. A common thing I tell myself is that "learning music theory will help me actually make something" and then at that point I have to wonder; how much theory should I actually know? I don't want to sound like any other artist, neither do I want to be trapped into one genre. Self expression is important in art, and I feel as if an arbitrary concept will hold back at that (especially with something as highly regarded as music "theory"). However, I also feel as if being completely clueless about it won't lead to any progress. Is it possible to develop even your own personal theory? I like emailing/asking questions to those I admire, and I thought taking this one to you would especially give me some sort of understanding. Have a great 2025!
126335.answer: for me the only genuine understanding is the part i arrive at independently by myself probably the majority of musicians nowadays go straight to sound, without having any intermediary silent paper stage. the silent paper thing can be fun, but it's a specific thrill that does not need to be the default way, and probably is only possible if you have sufficient experiencing making audible music it's like taste. how much taste theory do you need to know? wait what the heck is taste theory anyway it's like meeting a new person and falling in love with them. first it's important to buy and read a book that someone else wrote about how to fall in love with that person, in order to do it correctly. no i'm just kidding, this is not the case i personally am unable to understand any theory unless i've come up with it on my own. even if i know someone else may have found exactly the same thing before, it won't make any sense to me until i do it myself. This may be true for anyone, but i find it even more violently true for me than for others. i'm sure it has advantages and disadvantages i was thinking of combining 2025 and 2026 together actually

126336.question: If light is the only thing that's constant every where in the universe, then why is it so prone to mistakes? Why is light affected by gravity so that we see eg. stars that are behind the sun in a different place than they actually are because of the sun's gravity? Why could we see the back of our head if we looked to the side at the event horizon of a black hole because the light particles orbit around the black hole? The back of my head clearly isn't where the light indicates it to be. The fact that the speed of light is constant makes it seem so divine, but does it have to be so weird then? Also, if you fell inside a black hole, nothing might happen to you for hours and you would see the entire universe compressed into a increasingly smaller circle in your vision, the rest of which is complete darkness. Do you really think the black hole just swallows you "away" from the rest of the world or where would you go??? It seems like a place outside of our universe and I'm fascinated and confused because maybe some of my "why" questions could still be answered through math. Maybe we lack a dimension in our awareness to understand all this, but yeah I wanted to share my thoughts and confusion
126336.answer: light doesn't actually indicate where it is. you've just seen so much of it in normal earth circumstances that you've learned to use it to interpret where things are. If you go (or look) to somewhere far into another world with where different circumstances apply, you will have to re-learn how to interpret it i'm not sure, but the answer is usually even more divine than you expected it's hard to fully understand things so far away when we have literally never spent a day off earth

126407.question: what the hell is a kelvin and why is it used to measure temprature
126407.answer: basically Lord Kelvin one day got frustrated with all the 'negative' temperatures in celsius and said 'why cant we start the thermometer actually at the lowest possible temperature?' 126811.question: I once had a dream you befriended a little orange cat who would come and visit you in the darkness of night. You were always very happy to see your tiny visitor and greatly enjoyed her company whenever she decided to stop by. But it very much had the feeling that she would come and go as she pleased without much consideration for your opinion on the matter. Typical feline. So very fickle. You can never make them behave like a dog despite wishing they would. Which reminds me! Later in that same dream you then had a dog named Vinegar! (The name makes me laugh for multiple reasons) Vinegar seemed to be very loyal and quite affectionate, but she also had a bit of a stubborn streak. You'd try to walk her to where you wanted to go and she would just stop dead in her tracks and refuse to move. "She likes to do this. If I just act like I'm going to leave she'll follow me. She always does." But she just laid there, watching you walk off with your head turned around like an owl watching her in return expectantly. Vinegar never did follow in that dream. Ultimately you had to go back for her with a leash in hand before she got up with a wagging tail to greet you.

126901.question: Have you heard about AQAL / Integral Theory? It is a mental framework that describes phenomena in terms of "holons," which are nested hierarchies. It explains why a lot of phenomenon in the world tend to exhibit similar behaviors, and it explains a lot of phenomenon in the world as things that develop across time. It talks about how some humans just naturally develop into this type of "holon"-based, development-based, Integral-based world view. I learned about it and went "geez this seems very similar to how I view the world currently but is more articulate and thought-out." 127249.question: i have come to realize that i also need to come up with music and lyrics at the same time. buuuuut that means that the purely instrumental ideas i have saved are useless because i dont want to make instrumental music. have you had an issue like this? any ideas on what to do? should i just give up on my old ideas and learn from my mistakes
127249.answer: now that you mention it, i'm not actually quite so honest when i say "i always do words+music altogether" because truthfully i have the same situation as you: i have tons of instrumental riffs and things on hand, they come to me in dreams, etc, and i do indeed use those. "might quit", "meet me in september", "corner store", and many others, are based on a main melody that came to me initially with no words attached. Not always the most pleasant way to work, having to search to the ends of the earth to try to figure out what words belonged there all along, but it can be done. but anyway, you can still also write songs where you do it all together, and then you can mix it up even more by doing it other ways too, like 'title first' is a really fun way to do it; like, 'Sick of having songs with lame titles? what kinds of titles do you wish your songs would have?' and then think of some, and then blam, throw them into a list and then that's a super fun exercise for next time, which is basically 'melodify one of those titles' and then wait until yet a third time to turn that melodified line into the rest. anyway my point is there's lots of different fun methods, and there is no reason to restrict yourself to just one. have a blast

127276.question: I've been learning piano for a little while now, but up until about 2 years ago, I was almost exclusively studying classical music. However, I've more recently begun studying some (rather simple) jazz standards from the Real Book. Often, I have to practice playing the right hand melody of a piece, while playing the chords in the left hand. Usually, getting the right hand melody isn't too difficult, but it can be really challenging for me to get the chords in the left hand. It's not that I don't know the chords-most of the chords I can figure out-but that it takes me some time to figure a lot of them out; there's a whole process of analysis of the musical chord notation in front of me before I actually play the chord. This makes it so that, unless I "cheat" by writing in the names of the notes of some chords in the music, I have to stop my playing, figure out the chord, and resume playing. Do you have any tips on improving sight-reading when playing melody + chords? Is this just something that gradually improves with practice?
127276.answer: things certainly improve with experience but make sure you are enjoying yourself. i don't have any specific advice about your musical situation because your background is the polar opposite of mine, so you're kind of getting at everything in reverse order from me

127365.question: Do you prefer crispy or savory rotisserie chicken
127365.answer: the problem here is i've never been able to understand the meaning of the word savory. i used to assume it has fallen mostly out of use, but given that you've just used it, along with plenty of other people, i'm gradually beginning to realize that this is entirely my own problem. Actually, now that i think about it, the problem just got worse. Just when i'd begun to figure out, at the very least, that "savory" might be considered an opposite to the word "sweet" (and i can't even figure out what that would be), you've just implied that it might be actually the opposite of "crispy." This leads me to all kinds of bewilderment, such as "is it not possible for something to be soft and sweet?" So in conclusion i'd say i have even less of a grasp on the meaning of the word savory than i did just moments ago
