127668.question: what does it mean that melodic minor is only raised on "the way up." what if the melody doesn't go straight up or down
127668.answer: here's the way it happens: music is made, music happens, and then one day someone comes along and notices, either in their own music or someone else's, they notice "oh hey, i think i see a pattern, a certain type of habbit that some of us seem to be doing in music". and someone gives it a name and tries to summarize what the 'rule' is. it's possible that whoever named this one was listening to march of the broomsticks, maybe they weren't. But here's the golden rule: if you hear about a rule and it doesnt click with you, or you dont like it or you dont get it or you dont think it works, case closed. you dont need it, you dont want it, dont use it. you dont need to worry about it, and it's none of your business. The only tricks and patterns in music you ever need to worry about are those ones that you can hold in your hand and feel like "yes! i get it! i like this one, and i'm even ready to give it my own name if it doesn't have one already!"

127722.question: Growing up i always wanted to create things with computers. I loved programming and art, and I made little games or websites about things I liked. I think I internalized the praise of the people around me and started making things to impress other people instead of making things to enjoy myself. I stopped putting things in my work that represented me, because I was worried that critique of the work would feel like critique of me. I would work harder on things that impressed from a technical standpoint instead of something that spoke from my heart. I strived for 'perfection,' and as a result, my 'tech art' has become significantly more 'tech' than 'art'. I feel like I can no longer express myself. Any creative thing I can think of doing reminds me of all the stuff I did when I was in middle school, and I shudder at those memories which I have now deemed 'cringe.' I feel like the most important part of my artist brain has frozen over, and I'm worried I'll never be able to thaw it. Help???

127760.question: were you completely and utterly self taught in music? i just can't fathom having your level of talent, was it just a method of "play around and find what works" or did you have tutorials? how long did it take you to learn from scratch until your first proper song/jungle? was there a level of obsession/crazy interest to get started, and what kept you going? apologies for all the questions - cheers.
127760.answer: i honestly feel music is about as teachable as walking i don't have anything even close to a reliable way of calculating when 'scratch' was, what 'scratch' means, when or what the first 'song' was, what 'proper' means, .... it's lifelong. also certainly true that my earliest stuff ever shown on this website was likely created AFTER already having a number of years of experience in music greater than the lifespan of many of the listeners. this is probably an indication of my insecurity more than anything else it's common for me to latch magnetically onto a subject, or a skill, and drill into it obsessively for many weeks continuously. But here's the thing, there was a defining moment around when i was 12 when i had a realization that goes like this: "hmmm, i'm noticing that out of all the....approx 297 of these types of obsessions i've had so far in my life, i feel like at least 211 of them have been music related". Basically it became impossible to ignore that music was the most pervasive common thread between such a high percentage of these phases, and so i knew it wasn't going away. That being said, even to this day it's still not the entire picture. and yet it still keeps delivering new crazes in new ways

127794.question: how do you make your videos look like you don't care about the visuals but In reality you deeply care about every single frame?
127794.answer: i'll tell you exactly how. If you care deeply about every single frame, you'll never get anything done. you'll never finish any work, no one will ever get a chance to view it, you'll never get through it. So basically what happens is, when you spend years and years and years in that state, knowing you'll never finish or achieve anything if you care so much about every frame, eventually you learn that the only way out of this predicament is to, by some miracle, care much much much much much much less. i think you'll find that this scenario produces exactly the kind of results you described

127801.question: One thing I have noticed in a fair number of your songs is the tendency for an instrument to appear often for nothing more than a single phrase or as an ornament. I am a big fan of the diversity that this lends to your sound, since it makes each listen feel like a new 'choose your own adventure' for which parts to focus down and study. I was wondering what thought goes behind these moments. Additionally, I was curious whether you have nicknames for certain sounds that you use (I admit that I do and am quite partial to alien trumpet, grumpy duck, etc.) I tend to personify sounds when I compose and that personality bleeds through into the parts they encompass, especially in the realm of synthesis where pre-established emotional connotations for sounds don't exist where they do for other instruments.
127801.answer: the technique that creates the results you're talking about is kind of surprising because it kind of works backwards from the way you might think. i discovered it in 2015 and i will talk about it at great length at some poine if i haven't already i name sounds the same way i'd name anything. anything to help me identify it. animal names are certainly not off limits, but also fairly common is to refer to the name of the project i used it in for the first time. for example, 'pope phone' is probably the sound of the phone ringing when they called the pope to ask about the crusades that one time. perhaps i'd have one called 'violence bubbles' for that bubbly sound in the 'violence dont do it jingle'. and so forth

127890.question: Do you schedule your time between idea generator, thing finisher and thing selector? If yes, how?
127890.answer: when it's time to produce a new project, this is usually the full routine, if i feel i have enough time: first i'll do a big round of idea gen. so i'll come up with a whole pile of new ideas. file them away. Then, if i feel i have time, i'll do a bunch of rounds of middle-writing. which basically means you select an item (from the master list, not from the new items necessarily) and do a bit of writing on it, take it to the next step. Then once i've done that for a handful of items, then i'll switch to Selection, which is when we're actually choosing the item to be produced next. side note, you also need an idea-catcher, because new ideas will hit you at surprising hours of the day or night

127995.question: do you find creative ideas to be better or more valuable when they come out of nowhere versus when you make yourself come up with them? i find myself doing both but the former tends to be wayy more creatively fulfilling/cathartic although it happens super rarely, while the latter is a way more reliable way of making things for me but i often find myself not caring nearly as much about it if i do it that way
127995.answer: no need to discriminate. you can have both, you can do both, you can use both. there are advantages and disadvantages to each. the free gifted ones have the advantage of having a mythical quality to them and sometimes they are way deeper and more genuine sounding, but the disadvantage of course is that you have no control over when you get them, and also sometimes they're kind of bland or maybe even just something that already belongs to someone else. But for your idea-gen sessions, while it may seem like you could never get that same sparkle, the tip i have for getting the most out of the idea-gen is just do a lot. do A LOT. try to make the first 12 bad on purpose. Once you loosen up, you'll forget you're doing this and it will be essentially just like you're dreaming while you're awake, once the pressure is off. Also, ...... here's the other thing, when you do a lot of idea-gen all day, it will actually loosen you up so that when you take a break, or maybe in bed tonight or tomorrow, you'll find that you'll be suddenly receiving more of the rando gifts than you otherwise would. so it's a win-win. beyond that, just add them all to the same club and later down the line you'll find there's no need to discriminate between which ideas came from which methods. there's other methods too by the way

128149.question: A few years ago I got the opportunity for a job on the other side of the country and decided to take only the belongings that I could take on the train and try out something different for some indeterminate amount of time. I've been living very minimally and am learning about and working on some very specific things at an insane rate. Never would have thought I would be where I am. But... I've not been creating or performing music with myself or other people. The new thing has taken over the obsessive and creative energy part of me. The extent of the physical practicing I do is playing with drum sticks on the floor sometimes (but like maybe a few times a month). This would sound insane to the me from a few years ago. Maybe I care about the new thing more? I'm not sure. It's very technicalresearchy work, and I work on well defined problems and explain them with precise language and equations as well as more ill defined engineering problems with pragmatism. I care deeply about these things (mainly a sort of NEEDING to find some truth or answer), but they never seem to invoke feelingsthat truly match my experience of music. The only times I get that feelingof awe and verge of tears thing is when listening to a song. Usually it quickly fades though and the mind is back racing around trying to work on my research. Do you relate to any of these kinds of things? I don't know if this phase is one part of making my future creations better or if I'm in a trap. To be clear, I view the things I'm working on now as an example of those creations, but they feel less real somehow. I'm making the assumption that there are some similarities to working in "all the departments" for your productions or getting really nerdy about whatever you do.
128149.answer: music is a magical power but, as i always say, it's usually only part of the picture. so you're really making the world go round by developing your non-music side here

128273.question: i'm learning the guitar. do you think it's just a matter of time and practice before i can play ehat i think/what i hear? my left hand feels so clumsy when switching chords and my index finger stretches outwards when my pinky presses down and i don't know if that shouldn't happen. i feel like i don't know where exactly to learn the basics of "harmony." it feels like constructing chords requires some knowledge of harmony amd music terminology that i don't really know. i want to make music. i have come up with and recorded little melodies i thought of, but how do i do that with... chords? also, chord melody is a concern for me. if i want to play chord melodies, is it the same as playing the chords of a scale based on the intervals between the notes? HARMONY IS CONFUSING! i get the magic of harmony, adding notes on top of notes and all, but i have no idea where to start or how to improve. also constructing chords or harmonies on guitar isn't as intuitive as piano. or is it? i just want to play the beautifully rich sounds i hear in like Chick Corea's and Stevie Wonders' stuff, or in McCoy Tyner's, or Barney Kessel's work too... please help me, give me some direction. i know you're more piano-and-drums-and-bass, but please help! i hope i have explained my problem to you sufficiently
128273.answer: yes but don't forget to have fun right there, in your own life, in your own experience, with your favorite instrument(s) fine, but it really won't work right unless you discover it actually YOURself, with YOUR emotions. Everyone on earth who's ever tried to 'explain' how music and harmony works has essentially explained it wrong, and effectively you will too, in a new way not quite like anyone else's. that's why you have to find this yourself. then later you can make friends with all the other people who found similar things but slightly different i'd say if you are in '1 note at a time' mode, just start playing around with maybe SOMETIMES allowing 2 notes. for example if you have a melody, find just ONE note in the melody that can have a helper note with it at the exact same time absolutely not so is speaking, and making coherent word sounds with your tongue and mouth shape. i bet you would never be able to explain how you do that. and yet, somehow, after years of fumbling around, you've got it now and it's totally natural to you yes i think i'd recommend the above approach, to harmonize just 1 melody note with one other note, at just one moment of your favorite song melody harder in some ways, easier in other ways just like learning a language, the bad news is it takes a long time, the great news is that if you actually are enjoying yourself enough to stay in the game for long enough, there is literally no stopping you from being just as good as any of your favorite names. but you're gonna have to taste the food for yourself, one bite at a time

128319.question: You've mentioned in the past how your work process has 3 roles in it, the idea-creator, the idea-chooser and the idea-finisher. I wanna hear how you think the chooser works, cause oftentimes I find myself with loads of different cool ideas that I want to realize, and what ends up happening is that I get a bunch of unfinished scraps which I don't have the motivation to finish, or which I'm frustatingly unable to figure out how to complete. How does the chooser pick the best ideas so that the creator doesn't get bogged in unhelpful unfinished projects?
128319.answer: it's more roles than that, but that may have been in context of someone's specific question about their own process there's no need for the list to bog you down. the list is a well of opportunity. When you the 'procucer' decides "it's time to produce something", the 'selector' then goes into the list, and, by some method, makes a selection, and hands the selection to the producer. And then the producer produces that selection, and the selector does not make a selection until the producer has produced the previous selection. So the only burden, is basically what the selector selects. and yes it's a lot of pressure on the selector to make a selection that everyone is happy about, but there's no need for the LIST to be a burden. it's just the selection that's the burden. but of course it's not a burden, because the fun fact here is that any idea can be worked good. In either case, whether or not you love the selection, your motivation for following through on it might often be the sheer excitement of what you can produce next. i think the power of this method probably comes from a firm agreement you have in the scheduling department to simply continue to produce things diligently one after another, as a coping strategy for the overwhelming potential at stake

128389.question: I've been thinking about happiness lately, what it is and what it means to be happy. I've landed on: happiness is love. Love for other people, the world, music, everything. The more you love, the happier you'll be. I'm not sure there are very many things in the world worth loving, though. I think I hate a lot of things, and I'm not sure how to start loving or if I'll ever be able to. Have you ever had similar thoughts? I'm a big fan of yours and I appreciate what you've shared with the world. Thank you.
128389.answer: what i find is, every time i come up with an exact definition for happiness, at some point within days or weeks that formula crashes. and a slightly new form of happiness rises from that crash, defined in a slightly new way. it turns out to be a fairly stable ocean, as long as i don't try too hard to get pinned down to one exact definition of happiness. however i will confess that 'building' and 'learning' tend to repeatedly save the day for me, again and again and again and again

128426.question: I'm using a digital synth and one of the presets is doing this thing where the low end and some of the higher end will sort of build up slowly and then go back down slowly. I really like the sound other than this aspect, but I can't figure out how to turn it off. Which setting controls this on a synth? Do you know what it's called when this sort of thing happens?
128426.answer: look for LFO, shut those all off, look for attack/release, set those to 0. look for things being controlled by 'filter cuttoff' and turn those off yes, i call it "they are catering toward non-players. they want to make sure the sound sounds cool and plays itself even when you are not playing it. The problem of course, for you, the artist/player, is that you're not free to play the instrument yourself, so you will find yourself painstakingly turning off all of this auto-play stuff, and returning the power to wheels and knobs you can turn with your own sentient hands"

128457.question: i have trouble finishing songs and coming up with parts that are consistent with the previous parts and the song as a whole. I usually have a pretty good idea of the "sound" im going for, but oftentimes i cannot convey it onto actual notes and instrumentation. Typical scenario is I have a pretty cool intro and section A and maybe chorus, but when I try to build on it to create more sections/choruses/bridges it just feels like a different song stuck onto the first one and not like a fitting continuation. The problem intesifies when i try to "finish" a song after more than an evening or two pass, but i'm not always able to find time for it. Do you have any advice to writing parts of songs that are consistent with the previous parts?
128457.answer: the most immediate advice that comes to mind for your particular situation is this: some of those words you used, "Section A", "chorus", "build", "bridge", "consistent", "writing parts", "continuation", "fitting", i think you urgently should forget all of those words immediately. Not that they aren't good words, but in your situation i think i would advise you to forget those words immediately, they seem to be really suffocating you and holding you back quite tragically here

128655.question: In your answer to someone asking whether or not you liked imaginary numbers, your answer was: ' i do now, ever since i started thinking of positivity and negativity as a full circle instead of just binary' Could you elaborate? I hold a linier view of positivity and negativity.
128655.answer: think of positive 1. on the right side of the number line. it's totally positive, always positive. 1 times 1 equals 1. Now think of negative 1, on the left side of the number line. always negative. Negative 1 times negative 1 equals positive 1 (the negatives cancel out). but imagine that these two points (left and right, negative and positive) are actually part of a circle that goes all the way around. 1 straight up would be a number called "i" in mathematics. imagine that this number can't decide whether it's positive or negative. it's half positive half negative. So what's i times i? 'i' can't decide whether it's positive or negative, so you take one of each. like 1 times -1. the result is negative 1. And this is of course exactly the definition of i, it's the square root of negative 1. Directly straight down would be negative i, which of course also squares to negative one because like the upper i, it also can't decide whether it's positive or negative so you also get one of each, except technically in the opposite order

128678.question: What do you find is the best way to deal with burnout? I feel like needing to create stuff but not having the energy or creativity to do it is an endless cycle. It ends up with sessions working on music where I'm just frustrated with no creative spark to follow. I guess another way to put this question would be how do I go about generating that creative spark? because once I have an idea I can easily follow it and then the music just writes itself.
128678.answer: in your case i would suggest venturing briefly into some other areas besides music. Here's maybe the most important reason why: one of the things most sorely missing from most music is the non-musical elements. And, one of the most sorely missing elements from non-music is actually a musical element. Music and non-music are best friends and co-conspiritors. So if you've been *only* on the music side, and you're feeling bland and tired currently, i mean this is the perfect time to explore the other side of the coin because let's face it, you're gonna need both sides anyway

(but again..... what if i could make it good? that's why i'm scared to delete) just suspend everything else in my life and try to write and record as many songs as humanly possible? some combination of all of these? the problem with recording is..... it takes forever. like actually forever. anyways, sorry for the brain dump. just curious what your thoughts on the matter might be
128681.answer: enjoy and cherish it. and use it for its immensely useful purposes of course not of course not of course you can. probably even more fun to make the bad ones good than to stress about 'ruining' the 'good' ones how about doing a set. do like 10, see what you can learn from it. you can apply those lessons to the next 10 you do after that i understand the overwhelm, but there is no need to panic here. you are in fine hands yes, i can understand that i have some strange news for you: simplicity is skyrocketing in value; for many reasons, not the least of which would be that it may enable you to actually 'accomplish' something, which is probably starting to feel pretty priceless right about now

128697.question: Could you elaborate on the music and non-music thing. it seems to come up a lot in your answers but I'm not sure what you mean.
128697.answer: ok, this answer might make you feel frustrated, but your question makes me feel frustrated, through no fault of your own. my response to what you've asked is, "what don't you understand about it?" that being said i realize there's no answer to what i've just asked you and i apologize for that too music and non-music are always found together, in support of each other. For example: a song featured in a movie. You usually like the song better when it's in the movie, and it also makes the movie better to have the song in it. Another example: background music in a movie-- the music is the music, and the non-music would be the dialogue and what's happening in the scene. the music is there to make the scene stronger (hopefully). Another example: Joey Your-favorite-artist, singing a song. the music would be the music, and the non-music would be the words and ideas being expressed, or even the identity and personna of the artist, to whom you may feel a special connection. Another example: an instrumental song by Ricardo the Really Good Xylophone player. even if there's no words in the song, the non-musical element here is Ricardo himself and perhaps the crazy hat he's wearing, on the album cover, which you probably can't help thinking about when you listen to the music. Ok so now you may ask me this: What if you are going shopping in a store and you hear the same xylophone song, WITHOUT knowing who the artist is or seeing his crazy hat. you're probably thinking, "aha, here's a situation where it's just the music and no non-music" NOT TRUE, the non-music here is obviously YOU SHOPPING, which when combined with the song creates an unforgettable shopping experience

128713.question: What is mastery? I believe it is when you don't have to think about doing something, like you've mastered a language when you don't have to think about how to order the words and the vocabulary. 128713.answer: it's the idea of acquiring a skill 100%. of course you can argue all day about when or when not to use that word, because like all words it can be used a little loosely. But your analogy for language still holds fine for computer programming. you were saying a professional language user no longer thinks, while the pro computer programmer still does think, well that's not true -- a professional language user is still thinking about the thoughts they are expressing, but not thinking about language. and just the same, a pro computer programmer is thinking about the functionality they wish to achieve, while no longer thinking about the punctuation and syntax they are using

128733.question: Hi. recently, i have been struggling with communication. I seem to be unable to smoothly form any coherent phrase or sentence on the fly. I do not know whether it is caused by a new-found inability to form thoughts or whether it is induced by a lack of lingual ability or whether it is both at once. What would you have done if you have found yourself in a situation similar to this ?
128733.answer: reading between the lines here, i think i'm seeing a couple of things happening. it's possible that your written language has recently leveled-up in its preciseness, which is distracting for your speaking life because speaking thrives in totally different ways. and now you're distracted by some new and more 'perfect' higher standards of precision that you've recently started to enjoy in written language. On the other hand, a totally different reason for the symptoms you've described; if you're talking to someone you regard very highly, and you feel anxiously eager for them to respect your.... 'correctness' of language use, then this can cause you to fall apart. because let's face it, good speaking communication requires a bit of something much rougher around the edges. and you're having trouble relaxing because of the fear that you might...... misconjugate

128957.question: i get a weird mix of awe and jealousy when i see people making things sometimes. because sometimes you come across people that are amazing at a whole bunch of different creative things, like making music, and drawing, and writing stories, etc. meanwhile, i'm sitting here trying to be good at just one of those things, and still not managing to get anywhere close. and it makes me feel inspired, because those people are awesome and cool, but also kind of defeated, because i feel like whatever i make will always be bad in comparison. and i know you're not supposed to compare yourself to other people, that you just have to focus on improving on your own work. but it's hard for me to do that, because i want to see what other people do so i can learn from it. so, how do i learn from others without comparing myself to them? i just feel so frustrated having all these ideas for things i want to do and make and never being able to execute them in a way that lives up to other people.

129362.question: i get this thing where i feel "right" "good" "different in a good way" and often times the consequence of this is to try to capture it in a bottle for either others consumption or my own consumption in the future, when the feeling is gone. But I realize that often times that desire and process is external to the feeling, thus killing it in the process, and nothing left to capture. Do you find that music allows for this process to persist while hopefully capturing some of it in the process? Sometimes the right words come to express it, but whenever the goal is to express what it is, it feels like it leaves, it scares it away. its like a magnet thats attracting something by being, but as soon as it wants to attract something it faces it, and by that action gives it the opposite pole. I feellike maybe it is more important to let this feeling permeate more and moreand not worry about capturing it. and maybe later ill be so familiar with it that i can draw a map to it, instead of trying to capture it which seems futile.
129362.answer: every artist is familiar with this phenomenon. it may seem like a bizarre relationship, but this is the entire nature of who and what we are, and the entire conscious experience. 'Capturing', despite being so 'impossible', is actually meant to be the greatest game you can imagine

129519.question: If you were gonna say no, But changed your mind to say yes when you thought about it. What did you reaally think about that would turn your initial answer around to then abswer the opposite. What was your thought proccess?
129519.answer: let's look at some examples. someone said "Why do you think people started building things? Maybe Boredom?" my first instinct was no, this is absolutely not the reason for building. building things is because you want to do a lot of things that you can't do because you don't have the tools to do it. so you need to build things to help accomplish what you need to. 'boredom' seems like a very wrong way to describe the root cause. but then i was trying to figure out what is the cause behind wanting to do more complex things than were ever possible before. and it became harder to deny that 'boredom' COULD be a way to describe this, even though i'd probably prefer to use a word like 'curiosity'. i suppose it could be argued you could be curious about the future while being bored of the past. so ultimately i couldn't really disagree with the person's initial suggestion Let's look at another example: someone said "do you love satiation". at first i just didn't recognize the word. so i probably would lean toward no. then i did some surface level research and also remembered the word "insatiable", which is a word i like to use, especially while rubbing my fingers together to comminicate the concept of an unquenchible desire. and this led me to the conclusion of heck yeah i'd love to be satiated Let's look at just one more example, because "where there's 2, there's more" Someone said "Have you ever had a fever where the only prescription was more cowbell?" my first instinct was, this is not a question, this is a quote, from a famous saturday night live sketch starring christopher walken. therefore the person asking this here is not really asking what this is asking, they're just repeating a quote. and so to stay grounded in these situations i often use the cold hard truth as a go-to. my instinct was to say no, because i have so much to say about what it means and what it takes to really assemble music arrangements, it just felt initially so unlikely that this bit would actually ring true. But after thinking about it for a moment, it suddenly occured to me that this happens all the time. in the course of music production, it is absolutely not at all uncommon to find yourself deeply hankering for a cowbell at certain choice junctures

But look, let's get down to earth here: the world's greatest piece of cake, ...... that's great. That's something people are really gonna be excited about. 129671.question: i have this problem where whenever i'm walking around, sort of improv singing, i can sometimes come up with REALLY good melodies or a REALLY good chorus, so i instantly find myself wanting to make that a full song, but then when i get a pen and paper, i just realise i have no idea how to start the song to eventually get to that good chorus part and no matter how hard i try i never figure it out have you ever dealt with this? eitherway do you know how i can solve this (if so then how?)?
129671.answer: sure, i've spent my whole life dealing with this this is much easier when your starting idea actually belongs at the beginning of the song. if the starting idea is in the middle, you're kind of screwed. the songwriting gods are never comfortable when you try to do it out of order. but here's a trick, maybe: try to go forward from the chorus and see what comes after the chorus. if you're lucky you will end up at the chorus again soon. then you'll have a pretty good hint

I feel as if I actually know nothing about creating art. I feel like there's at least Some kind of deeper overarching pattern I should be aware of, and knowing it would make the songwriting process way more straightforward. I get the feeling that my "gift" for writing songs is only temporary and I'm bound to completely lose it one day, as it's based on nothing and has no solid foundation.
